The house had many things attractive about it:

* It was in a lovely neighborhood
* It had a large kitchen
* It was surrounded by pretty trees
* Its house looked exactly as it appeared on the street, and was very well renovated when he had visited

The house had none of those things that attracted him, so his thoughts were far from pleasant when he discovered that it would cost $90 for a single night's stay. But there was nothing else for him to do but to check out the house and take a night or two off work to spend a week there. Jennie needed an extra job to support herself as well, and it was a great chance for her to learn more about decorating and to see the world.
When his name was called for check in, it was with mixed emotions that he saw the house that he was about to call home for the next three weeks. Jennie immediately knew that the house was not the house for her. The kitchen was small, the bathroom had a small window over the toilet. No, this was not going to work for her at all.
It was a house that was about a decade older than she was, but had an appealing design. She would have thought it would be nice, but when he opened the door, there he stood in a room that was dark and cool, and full of holes from the ceiling and down the walls of the room, and all of the windows had been taken off the wall and the frames of the windows were broken.
Now, it was late afternoon, and he turned to walk away, but he was stopped from doing so by a door knob. An hour before he had been able to push his shoulder against the door knob and turn it, now the force of the door was coming through and pulling him into a new, strange room. He was being greeted with a heavy wooden door with no locks on it, and he was being shut out into a dark, damp basement room, with a few walls that had been torn out, and a bunch of the holes were still standing open. Even the door was rusted shut, there was not power to the house, so there was nothing keeping him in the room, now just a dark hole.
He turned around to go downstairs again and this time, he didn't have the choice. He stood there, unable to go down into what he hoped would be what he'd been expecting

Output: The body of a human and a tree.

Answers:[1]

A. A bag

B. An oven

C. A box

D. A ball

E. A bucket

Answers:[2]

1. A bag
2. A bucket, also called an urn or a drum

Explanation: A non-flexible object with a definite shape is an object with a solid backbone that can be stretched only slightly. A flexible object that is stiff and flexible at the same time (a ball) is also a bag, but it must be held to be stretched or stretched a lot. Also to be stretched is a ball inside a bag. A urn is called a drum because it is made in a round shape with a body. This is the same shape as a bag: a cylindrical object with a cylindrical body. The only difference between the two is their material. The most common material in the bag is nylon; the drum is made from plastic. The drum is not flexible and is always solid, even when it is hot. A bag can only be stretched as much as the bag can be stretched.

I have a child that is 5'3". I was asking what to do for the day when she came home from school. She had a friend with her (5'7") that were making a lot of noise (mumbling and being annoying to say the least). I looked up at the ceiling and said, "There's only one answer to this question: "No."
I would really appreciate your help! Is it okay to continue to let this happen? I have worked with her to control her noise level. My concern is that if I try to control her, she will start to resent me and start doing it herself.

(Click to show or hide answer)

* You need javascript enabled to see this answer.

Answer:

I can't answer that question from your question, but I am going to answer it from your post here.

If you were trying to help your daughter, you're right. You need to control her noise level to give her some self respect. But if you keep "fixing" the problem you're helping her to develop a problem that she will use against you later in life - and that you will be paying for. If you can't control her, try and give her a good role model (I know - but is her problem really that you're not her role model?). Is the problem that she is talking to people at a distance and when they hear it make noise, she gets scared?

If she is not the problem, then it should be a natural thing to say "No", she doesn't need to know what you were thinking...

I have read that children who are raised in a safe childhood setting exhibit behavior similar to that of adults. So this means if you could just talk to her and teach her to control her behavior, this would be helpful. You could also tell her that it is okay for her to mumble, but if she starts to yell, then to stop.

Just my 2 cents.

I have said the following before without hesitation to children.

A. If I do what you say, the next thing you do is get mad. B. If you do what I say, I’m going to get angry and hit you. C. If you do what i say, it’s not my problem. D. If you do what he says, the next thing I say is I’m not talking to him.

The objective is to write the following sentence to show how to construct a sentence.

I am writing a sentence that will show how to construct a structure sentence.

My sentence cannot begin nor end but if I follow the rules, it will.

The beginning is a prepositional phrase and an end is a preposition. We are not allowed to include the words "or" and "but" in the sentence since they do not appear in the sentence (that would be redundant and would get in the way of this).

The preposition "or" is not allowed in sentences that end a sentence with only one preposition.

The preposition is a common preposition. Not all prepositions of this kind are allowed and therefore not all common prepositions can end sentences. Ex: if I were to say:"I am writing a sentence", "write" becomes one of the options.

As long as there is at least one preposition in the sentence, prepositions are allowed. The preposition can only be used with a sentence that is not dependent upon one preposition and then it can end the sentence.

The preposition "but" is an irregular preposition. When used in a sentence alone, it can end the sentence, but when used in some other form of sentence, it can only do that. Therefore, it is a bad preposition to use, because it can put an ambiguity in writing. Because of this, as long as it shows that something is dependent on "and".

The preposition, "yet", is a conditional preposition. When used "yet" can never be used in conjunction with a sentence ending with "not" or a subject that starts with "me" or "I". The only way to use this preposition in a sentence is if it shows that something is conditional on some sort of future state. So this preposition, like the aforementioned "or", is not allowed.

When using prepositions, only one of them can show that something is conditional. For example, it is possible to end a sentence with a preposition, "yet" and one additional preposition. The preposition ending with "

In this lesson you learned about how a person's body gets rid of waste that is no longer useful. You learned about the processes a body uses to get rid of waste. There are waste-related things and waste-related things that are not. Examples include garbage, waste, wasted time, wasted effort, wasted energy, wasted money, and wasted happiness. You learned where the difference between waste-related and waste-related things lies.

You learned how waste and waste-related things and their associated feelings are feelings that have a specific psychological profile. You learned how psychological profiles can be used to help others understand waste and waste-related issues better. You learned about waste identification and about waste management. You learned that, in order to understand waste, you may need to do some research and some reading. You learned that psychological profiles are not objective and cannot be relied upon to be all-inclusive. You learned that psychological descriptions and descriptions in general aren't helpful to all situations. You also learned about the impact of psychological profiles and psychological profiles for our environment. Finally, you learned that, in the end, it is up to you to develop the capacity to look beyond your specific psychological profile or psychological profile descriptions to get to the root of a situation.

The class:
This is a course that requires students to use the skills needed to become a successful journalist, as well as to write critically. The purpose of the course is to allow students to become aware of the skills and habits needed in order to create a quality, professional news article. Students must also develop the skills needed to form and edit sources, both from other newspapers and their own. They must also learn how to use the Internet to access sources in order to research them. The writing course also focuses on the ability to write about all aspects of life. They will focus on current events within the greater community as well as current events in the United States.

The average monthly mortgage payments of a one- family home in this area will be $2,600 which equals about 4 days' worth of groceries. Which amount would you think the house cost?
Output:
Assuming that these amounts are true and that the person who made them does so in good faith, then he or she would be incorrect. If this person were correct, the people who were wrong would be unable to imagine that a one- family home costs more than $300 (at the median price of 3,541 dollars) per month; in which case the difference in gross monthly expenses would have more than been paid for.
### Explanation
The "average" is a very misleading statistic. Most people don't need to know how to budget and do chores in order to live well - the average household has more than what the data shows. While the calculation here is not precise, we need to be able to put the average in proper perspective. People have been asked to work from home and their expenses have more than doubled - they are now spending money that did not exist before - and many people in the U.S. cannot live on $300 a month.

I've also found some great resources on the internet regarding computerized tests. The computerized tests are often referred to as MCAS (McAuliffe Assessment, Testing and Reporting system), or PARCC (Program to Evaluate and Rating Children for Cognition and Development). The PARCC assessment is the most common test of this kind in classrooms today in the U.S. The PARCC assessment (and other computerized tests) provides a detailed look at each pupil’s reading level, writing abilities, and the ability to understand information. Through these assessments, education workers know how to help their students to succeed.

The PARCC assessment is fairly comprehensive (it covers everything up to 16th grade and includes information from reading (first grade) to math (16th grade)) and is used across the country (it is used in the UK, among other countries; it is also one of the tests used in most states).

I feel like computerized tests are great tools for education workers to assess learning, and they can be an effective way to keep an eye on student achievement. However, one of the drawbacks is that computerized tests can be difficult to interpret. As explained in my previous post, computerized tests are built on several different systems, which have their own idiosyncrasies and strengths.

One other problem with computerized assessments is that the results can be skewed. This can happen if multiple assessments—like one administered by different testing firms—are used to test a single student. A student with a poor score on one assessment could get a high score on another assessment. As a result, the score on the first test may be skewed lower than the score on a different test administered by a different testing firm.

When the test results end up being skewed, it undermines the results of the test when students begin to use the computerized scores to predict their grades. This can lead students and teachers alike to make unfair judgments about the value of the test on their own scores, which can increase the amount of studying that is required (time that would otherwise be spent focusing on the actual learning activity) while also undermining the overall learning experience.

In their book Sex At Dawn, Sigmund Freud refers to one of his students, Anna Freud, as "the daughter of a father of modern psychology" (emphasis added). Freud, having learned to identify himself with his father as a Jewish, educated, upper-middle-class German family, was not familiar with the many ways in which sex could be a function of culture, class, gender, and many other factors. Freud, himself a student of psychology, was also less well versed in the various modes of sexual expression available to heterosexuals; Anna Freud was a practicing lesbian.
With the advent of the Sexual Enlightenment of the late 19th century, the study of sexuality entered a new age and brought Freud and his wife Mary in touch with women's sexuality, both within relationships and outside of them (especially in relation to their extended family), and with the development of Freud's theories about sexuality and the family that emerged in the course of the '50s and '60s.
The '70s gave way to the '80s when Freud began to think about sexuality more broadly. His own daughters had begun to question his assumptions about sexuality, especially when it came to marriage. Freud's own attitude towards marriage was also affected by his work with his wife, Mary, throughout the '60s and '70s, a period in which Freud had been involved, in the first instance with his wife, in what could best be called an adulterous affair in the 1960s, when he believed Mary was not sexually attracted to him, and, with the eventual addition of a third wife (Margarete) in the '70s, Freud realized he might have been sleeping with his wife.

While this is not the story I told my class in college (a fictional one, I will admit), I believe it is a great example of how Freud came to think about gender as linked to sexuality.
Many people who believe homosexuality is an orientation or vice will not find your example of Anna Freud a particularly attractive one, but to my eyes, it is as relevant as that of my own parent's.
To some, homosexuality is an orientation or a vice, while to others, it isn't. Sexuality and gender and the family are closely related matters—many think Freud's theories about gender have much

Input:There are two ways to do business: by giving or receiving. The one who gives is the one who gets. The one who receives is the one who gives.  Output: 310

"Give" versus "Receive"

"Give" or "Return Value" is an equation where both the "give" and the "receive" are monetary.  "Give" is a cost and "receive" is a price. The return value is the average value of what was given plus or minus what was received by the "giveer."  The amount of "receive" is added to the money received to calculate the amount of income the "giveer" is getting.  This is the sum of the "receivee" and "giveer's" income.

An example of a "give" situation would be a loan.  A person makes a loan to someone else.  Then, when the loan is paid back and the person stops making monthly payments, the balance of the loan is now due on the "giveee", not the "give" - since the person still has a right to the property.  The bank may write that debt off in a tax deduction.

An example where the amount given is "receiveable" would be a gift.  Instead of giving a dollar amount, it may be a donation that the "giveer" puts towards paying for something someone else purchases with the "give" amount.

Some ideas to "give" are:

Giving money

Giving a present

Giving food

Giving shelter to another

Giving a home to another

Giving information

Giving a gift certificate so that the "giveer pays for the good he/she wants, not the product or service"

Giving money at one store, and not having to go to another store to buy the same gift

Giving a free ride on a bus, if someone else is riding the bus.  The "giveer" does not have to go pay for the ride because he/she wants to give the "free ride"

Giving to someone you do not know personally - someone you give an order to, something you need to take care of, someone that needs money.

Giving money to some friends to give to others.  This is not as much a "give" as is it is an "exchange."

If we are in an environment with light, we would know how we can use our shadows. For instance we can see the surface of the air with a shadow and use the shadow to guide us to the object in our environment. In reality, we don't use shadows but we use the air we can see with shadow to guide our movements. If we use the air, we will know that we need to look in different direction to know where we can pick up the object. If we see with the air, we will need our shadows because we would not know where we can pick stuff up with the air. So how is our use of shadows helping us to know where to look for the objects that we want to pick up?
That is a really interesting question, but it depends on our objective. Is it for finding the object in a certain area? Is it to get from one place to another? Is it to look for an object in a certain way?
It depends on your objective.

In the next post, let us have a look at how the use of the shadows helps us to find the objects that we want in a place.

The last example is what I expected. It was not very tricky, though the second sentence didn't seem to fit. The verb is not used in the sentence - Bob ran from the corner shop to his street. It is used in the sentence - He ran from the corner shop. So the word of the day is not either noun - shop or noun - word of the day.

You might try answering each category on the left with - noun - verb or adjective.

You see how this sentence gets confusing when you combine the verb form verb - verb and the noun - adjective - verb. And the last example is tricky. The word of day in the above sentence is not used to show the verb form verb verb - verb, but just to state that it is the verb - verb used in the previous sentence.

One question is what verb would you use if you put both nouns and verbs, like you have in the last example? If you use both nouns and verbs as you have in the sentence, the question is, which one would you use?

For the other questions, you'll need to do the following:

If you put both nouns - noun - noun, put in one noun after another, as in example 5, the answer is noun - noun, meaning that the verb form verb - noun is used. If you put in an adjective - adjective - noun, you'll need to put in one adjective before another, as in example 6, in which case the answer is adjective - adjective - noun. If you put in the adjective - adjective - verb, then you've gotten mixed up: adjective - adjective - noun - verb. So use only adjective - adjective - noun and adjective - adjectives - adjectives, such as in example 7.

"She did not have a clue" seems to be one of the most frustrating things for any teacher I've ever taught in. When I was a beginner teacher, that sentence went through my head more than most anything. That sentence is how I know why the word "incomprehensible" appears so often on tests of writing skills: a teacher has no clue--they're just not ready to figure it out.

When given two items, ask students to guess at the first answer you give them. If that's still too hard, have students guess how far the items go. Once they feel confident with this idea, they can try guessing how far each item is placed.

If students are struggling but know the correct answer for the first guess they've already made, have them pick two of the items and give them an answer, and let them keep guessing before you tell them the answer (if they've forgotten it). Then they'll still feel like there's a good chance they can guess a few more answers and do well!

Also: If you have a group of students assigned an answer at first, but they end up guessing, ask them to try guessing the two things that got them to the right answer. Make up extra questions in advance so that when they know both answers are right then they're not caught off guard.

You've now been trained to make an estimation of an amount of money.

Here's an exercise you can give students that uses money as input, but this time you're going to give them a list of numbers ranging in value between $1 and $10,000. Once you tell them what number is on the list (maybe you start with 15), have them multiply the list number by 1000 to get the dollar value of the item.

If any student guesses 10, you get 10 points for them.
If any students guess 15, you get 15 points for them.
So you've already got a good idea of how far apart numbers are in value so you can usually estimate how many point you'll get for guessing 10, 15 and 20 points. Just keep going. (Remember: just as math is difficult to visualize, it's not that difficult to calculate.)

You can always get points for your guesses if people guess your first and second guesses exactly (although you'd better be able to guess at least one correct guess before that occurs and you can start doing this correctly without too many points given in advance!) If someone guesses the last option, you only get one point for him. This is why the answer to what value a dollar is varies from person to person.

You could also have students give you their number of guesses and you can give the student who guesses most points in advance 10 points to show you that you're confident he or she got it right.

Question 5: How can I make myself happier?
Answer: If you want people to be more happy, then make them happy. If you want to make yourself unhappy, then make yourself unhappy. If what you want to do is to make yourself happy then get some exercise. When you are exercising you don’t feel like you are working, but that’s a sign that you are working. Another sign is how much you exercise. If you work at an office, you may be a little lonely. If you work in a home office, you will always have people around. Another sign that you are working is how much you do anything. You can’t just sit around and relax, you have to do something. What would you like to do that you never do? If you could never do anything, I guarantee you that you haven’t made any changes in your life.

This is a partial, non-exhaustive list of questions about Dora. All questions must be answered entirely correctly in order to get full credit.

You can search the entire web site for an explanation of any question (not just your question) if you want to know every answer.

To post, simply click on "Post Answer". When you first post, you are asked to enter exactly one sentence per post (just like a news article) - this is to keep the discussion clean.

If you have a topic to discuss in the Forum (ex. which color your eyes are, or if some of you like my music, or even which girl's eyes are prettier, etc.), feel free to start a topic of your own and post there. It is also a good idea to post on a forum that you use regularly, just to save people time searching through the entire site on a new one.

If your topic is not related enough to the other forum discussions, or if you are unsure of the topic's appropriateness or the answer to the question, then please feel free to say so. Just make sure to include in your post a brief explanation of the question you are posting, followed by a short description of any possible answer you might have, and a brief "Thank You"

Please remember to follow these guidelines for posting:
a. keep the topic short b. no more than 90 characters, do not exceed 10 lines c. be respectful e. avoid personal attacks d. post only when you have at least one real answer that is not part of another discussion.

These guidelines have been implemented to prevent spamming, harassment, and the repetition of questions that are already existing in other topics. They are in place not to limit the forum, but to prevent the forum from becoming too cluttered by posts that contain more than one answer.

If you'd like to see more forums on the same site, there are many places on the internet where you can have such discussions, from the online book "Debating, The Fun Way to Win Friends and Influence People" to the many online chat rooms.

To create and post in a Forum, you must first create a profile and then register using the profile page. After registering, click on the Post a New Topic icon at the top of any topic you are interested in and you are quickly ready to post.

To reply to a Discussion Post, you must use the "Post Reply"

You may have noticed that the answers to the two questions below are not the same. The answer to Question 1 is the same as the answer to Question 2

But, the answer to Question 2 is different from the answer to Question 1 - how do you explain this?

Answer : I explain the answer in the following manner:

This question is a simple question about probability and its application to a particular problem. It is a basic probability problem in which there are two possible answers, each having a different probability. The probability for A to be true is the probability that the car is available and would be returned on time. For B to be true, but less likely, the car is unavailable. Both probabilities for A to be true are one.

So, the best thing to do is ask people why they feel that way and don't expect your answers to fully explain why you think that - all you can do is share your answer for the question, and hope people will see whether your answer is similar to others or not.

The best thing to do is make a guess. You can do this by asking your audience what kind of answer they prefer - the simplest version is to get them to guess and then you can get them to make you a guess. If you ask a bunch of people the same question and get 5 different answers then maybe you can get 50% guessing and 50% guessing (since the odds would be 4 to 1 that you get the same answer as someone else), if you're lucky, that number would be 100%.

I have an opinion that the best answer is different than all the others answers - if the best answer comes from a small audience of people then perhaps it is because they are more likely to be influenced by it. I could be completely wrong about this but my guess is that for each "right answer" you receive, about half of the audience didn't receive it and half just didn't know you wanted it.

I'd like to hear your opinion, that is, what sort of answer you would prefer. I think you'd have to be very clear about whether you prefer the answers that are given or those based on your own guess - if the answer was based on an open ended guess it could be just as hard to predict as the answer based on an open ended answer.

I suppose you can't get any more objective

If you are asked to write a story describing one of two subjects, one of your best strategies will be to decide which subject you think will make a better story arc. To pick the better subject, ask yourself what your audience would most benefit from this story.

For example, if you were asked to write a story about the day a man was diagnosed with early onset cancer at age 60, that story would have to start at the diagnosis and go from there.

A much more interesting story might be told by an individual who, on the day he was diagnosed, didn’t know anything about cancer, and then learned after a lot of investigation that he had colon cancer. A: this charge is applied on the day the janitorial fee is calculated, so if you requested a service on the same day (and not the following day after), then likely not
B: it is applied to each cleaning request. If you used a self service cleaner then the fee would be $3
C: it would be applied to each cleaning service request, including the initial cleaning and the first one where you paid it.
D: it would be applied per person, but it would not be applied on the same day as cleaning request.
E: not applicable on the date a janitorial fee is billed, so if you only used the self service cleaner, then it is not applied to the first cleaning request where the fee was charged, but if you used the app/service in the day before and not a self service cleaner, then the fee would be applied immediately and the cost of the app/service should be taken into account when calculating how much would have been charged.
